body.p:
JACOB VOORSANGER,
EDITOR JEWISH SOUTH,
HOUSTON, TEXAS.

I have read with much interest your letter of March
20th and only regret, that my many occupations and the
intervening holidays prevented me from replying sooner. To
enter into the merits of our present discussion at once: you
denounce Bernstein and our give him some hard knocks
on the knuckles, yet pardon me, if I am still impressed
with the extraordinary similarity of the stories of Gen,
esis and kings. I have always been a devoted follower of
the science of philology, and especially under the rules
of that science B's deductions are perfectly admissible
But granted, that you are right on every point—what
about the Samson and Herakles comparison? Surely
there one finds more than accident, namely the drawing
on a common source of information. A few other examples.
In the last number of the Hebrew Review Dr. Haupt
satisfactorily proves, that the flood story is a transcript
(almost literally) from an Assyrian or Chaldean
story. I knew long ago that the first chapter of Genesis

was a use transcript from a like source. Enf. Graetz,
following the Frenchman Bertheau, identifies [Hebrew] and
[Hebrew] with Apollo (Helios) and makes [Hebrew] their
sister the same as Venus (the moon). [Hebrew] is
the the Etrurian Toelchin[?], Gr. [Greek], and by drop,
ping the S. which is perfectly permissible the Latins
had Vulcan (us) who was a blacksmith, as [Hebrew]
was the worker in iron and brass.

Be these things as they may, & much remains true
that we stand at the door of a revolution. What for,
merly has been the private opinion of scholars is now
becoming public property, and when a man like
Dr. Lilienthal [Hebrew] publicly proclaims (Hebrew
Review, page 130) that the Bible contains "legendary
parts," and that "especially the Mosaic Books are com,
posed of various parts, written and collected at var,
ious times" we have cause for serious meditation. If
this assertion be true than [Hebrew] is a licentia
scribenda, if not to denominate it by a harsher ex
pression; and the prophet who said [Hebrew]...
....[Hebrew] did not know anything about
what he was saying. Can you then be surprised

JACOB VOORSANGER,
EDITOR JEWISH SOUTH,
HOUSTON, TEXAS.

that we youngsters, who must follow the directions of
the and tendencies of the age are sadly perplexed? In view of
the foregoing I beg to represent to you that my diffi,
culty is not exactly the harmonization of the scriptures
with critics and criticism, but only how to apply the
letter so that the former may remain [Hebrew] I have
read much; thank God that my faith has not suffered,
and when in the article answered by you I quoted Hab,
bakkuk it was to indicate, that his golden rule
was indeed the only safe rule, and that not creed
but deed, not scholarly attainments, but humble work,
not scrupulous text-criticism, but pious compliance
with the text's demands were to lead to happiness.
Am I not right? What perplexes me is not how
to learn for myself, but how to teach my block and
my prof pupils. If I err for myself, it is simply
[Hebrew] but if I err in my teachings, is that
not unpardonable? Hence I criticized your talk.
I thought and still think—that our people cannot
yet stand the risk of radical text-criticism, and
that it is untimely to discuss before them works like

Of course I respect your reluctance to enter the field of
polemics, and I shall therefore not continue to write on this
subject. I have recently withdrawn from the J. S. mainly
because its proprietor is impractical and unmanageable,
but I shall not remain idle. I have a passion for writing
and as long as I can therewith serve the cause I am con
tent. I may, in course of time, develop into a "story teller,"
for I discover in one a growing taste for writing sketches
and tales, which have already given Koppel von Vloomburg
something of a reputation. I thank you for your kind advice
to "study the situation" it is really necessary, for my income
is beginning to be disproportionate to my expenditures. Hap
pily my dear people will raise my salary next month
with an additional #300. I have lately subscribed for the
new Wilna edition of the [?] and [Hebrew]; it will cost a
great deal of money, but I need a complete edition. Time
fails me to write more. I hope to be honored again with a
few lines, and with regards to Miss Morais and the
children I am sincerely yours
